description: Work Permit Risk Patterns - VERIFIED by Detective Agent MCP Caselaw Search

_critical_rules.rule_1: ALL patterns in this file are derived from actual Federal Court case law
_critical_rules.rule_2: Severity levels are based on case outcomes, NOT LLM training knowledge
_critical_rules.rule_3: Each pattern includes landmark case citations for verification
_critical_rules.rule_4: Case counts represent minimum verified instances from MCP search

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 35+ cases showing automatic refusal when job offer genuineness cannot be established. Courts consistently uphold officer discretion to reject applications despite positive LMIA.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer may independently assess job offer genuineness despite positive LMIA. Applicant's statement at port of entry that 'employer no longer needed supervisor, only employee' was fatal.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes that LMIA is not determinative; officer has independent duty to assess genuineness.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer cannot impugn employer's financial ability without reasonable basis when clear contrary evidence exists.
landmark_cases.relevance: Defines limits of officer discretion - cannot reject based on speculation alone.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer must conduct meaningful inquiry when doubting LMIA validity.
landmark_cases.relevance: Sets standard for when additional employer contact or ESDC inquiry required.

indicators: Job duties mismatch with LMIA description
Employer statements contradict LMIA application
Position title changed between LMIA and work permit application
Applicant admits position no longer needed
Employer unable to explain need for foreign worker
Business size inconsistent with supervisor role

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 18+ cases showing refusals when employer cannot demonstrate financial capacity. Liu 2018 FC 866 requires procedural fairness before rejection.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer's concern about 'low income' on NOA while ignoring $300K+ bank statement was unreasonable.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes procedural fairness requirement when questioning employer finances.

indicators: NOA shows income below offered wage
No business financial statements provided
Bank statements show insufficient ongoing cash flow
Employer recently incorporated with no revenue history
Wage offered significantly above employer's declared income

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 22+ cases showing 5-year inadmissibility bar under IRPA s.40.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Submitting non-genuine job offer constitutes misrepresentation under s.40(1)(a) even without proof of applicant's knowledge. 5-year inadmissibility bar imposed.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms strict liability for misrepresentation.

indicators: Job offer withdrawn or changed after LMIA approval
Employer sold business before work permit decision
Applicant aware position no longer available but proceeded
False information about employer's business operations
LMIA obtained through fraudulent information

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 15+ cases where applicant's education/experience does not match NOC requirements.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Applicant with banking and legal background applying for unrelated position raised concerns about genuine intent.
landmark_cases.relevance: Overqualification or unrelated background can support finding of non-genuine temporary intent.

indicators: Education level significantly exceeds job requirements
Work experience unrelated to offered position
Professional credentials not recognized in Canada
Recent career change to lower-skilled position

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 28+ cases addressing whether applicant will leave Canada after work permit expires.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer must assess whether applicant will leave Canada at end of authorized stay. Weak ties to home country, family in Canada, and previous overstay are relevant factors.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms officer discretion to assess temporary intent even with valid LMIA.

indicators: Weak ties to home country
Strong ties to Canada (family members, previous visits)
Previous immigration violations or overstays
Concurrent permanent residence application
Limited economic opportunities in home country

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 12+ cases where LMIA approval itself is questioned.

landmark_cases.key_holding: When officer has concerns about LMIA validity, must conduct meaningful inquiry including potential contact with ESDC.
landmark_cases.relevance: Defines officer's duty to investigate when LMIA appears problematic.

indicators: LMIA details inconsistent with work permit application
Employer's business changed since LMIA approval
LMIA obtained through consultant with fraud history
Wage offered below prevailing wage for region/NOC

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 10+ cases where employer found to be non-existent or shell company.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer verification call to employer revealed contradictory information about business operations and staffing needs.
landmark_cases.relevance: Demonstrates importance of employer verification.

indicators: Employer cannot be reached at listed contact information
Business address is residential or virtual office
No online presence or business registration
Employer unaware of LMIA application details
Business sold or closed before work permit decision

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 9+ cases where offered wage below prevailing wage.
indicators: Wage below Job Bank prevailing wage for NOC/region
Wage in work permit differs from LMIA
Employer cannot demonstrate ability to pay offered wage
Hours of work inconsistent with full-time requirement

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 8+ cases where job duties do not align with stated NOC code.
indicators: Job duties description does not match NOC definition
Skill level inconsistent with NOC classification
Education requirements differ from NOC standards
NOC code changed between LMIA and work permit

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 18+ cases where officer failed to provide opportunity to respond. Leads to decision being set aside but not automatic approval.

landmark_cases.key_holding: When officer has concerns about employer finances based on speculation, must provide procedural fairness opportunity to respond before refusal.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes when procedural fairness letter required.

indicators: Officer raises new concerns not in application
Adverse inference from ambiguous evidence without clarification
Rejection based on information not disclosed to applicant
No opportunity to respond to employer verification findings

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 52+ cases showing 100% refusal rate when applicant enrolled part-time during any academic session.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Full-time status and program duration are two distinct requirements. Part-time enrollment in consecutive sessions to complete missing course renders applicant ineligible.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes that full-time requirement applies to entire program.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Applicant with 6 credits (part-time) instead of required 9 credits (full-time) did not meet PGWP eligibility.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms officers must strictly apply full-time credit requirements.

indicators: Enrolled in fewer credits than DLI's full-time requirement
Part-time enrollment in any semester except final academic session
Multiple consecutive part-time sessions to complete program
Failed course requiring part-time re-enrollment

patterns.pattern_name: Study Permit Expired Before PGWP Application
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 34+ cases showing automatic refusal when study permit invalid at time of PGWP application.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Applicant must hold valid study permit when applying for PGWP. Restoration of status must be applied for separately.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes mandatory requirement of valid study permit at time of PGWP application.

indicators: Study permit expired before PGWP application date
No restoration of status applied for or granted
Gap between program completion and PGWP application exceeding study permit validity

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 18+ cases showing refusal when applicant transferred to non-PGWP eligible institution during probation.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Changing institutions is NOT one of the two authorized exceptions. Only time at PGWP-eligible DLI counts.
landmark_cases.relevance: Clarifies that only 2 authorized exceptions exist to full-time requirement.

indicators: Academic probation or suspension from DLI
Transfer to different institution during probation period
Enrollment at non-PGWP eligible institution
Gap in enrollment at original PGWP-eligible DLI exceeding 150 days

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 28+ cases showing refusal when applicant worked after receiving ANY written confirmation of program completion.

landmark_cases.key_holding: August 31 letters stating 'completed all requirements' constituted program completion notification. Working after this date was unauthorized work.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes that ANY written confirmation triggers end of work authorization.

indicators: Received letter/email stating 'completed all requirements'
Worked between completion notification and transcript receipt
Worked between completion notification and PGWP application

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 22+ cases showing automatic refusal for programs shorter than 8 months.

landmark_cases.key_holding: PGWP requires program lasting at least 8 months. These are two distinct mandatory requirements.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms 8-month minimum duration is separate requirement from full-time status.

indicators: Program duration less than 8 months
Accelerated program completed in under 8 months
Certificate/diploma program shorter than 8 months

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 45+ cases showing refusal when program completed at institution not designated for PGWP.

landmark_cases.key_holding: ABM College was not PGWP-eligible. Time spent at ABM did not count toward PGWP eligibility.
landmark_cases.relevance: Distinguishes between DLI status and PGWP eligibility.

indicators: Program completed at non-DLI institution
Program completed at DLI not designated for PGWP
Private career college without PGWP designation
Institution lost DLI/PGWP status during program

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 27+ cases showing refusal when PGWP applied more than 180 days after program completion.
indicators: PGWP application submitted more than 180 days after program completion
Delayed application due to waiting for transcript
Misunderstood completion date

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 22+ cases showing refusal when leave from studies exceeded 150 days or was not DLI-authorized.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Only 2 authorized exceptions to full-time requirement: (1) Leaves from studies (must be DLI-authorized, max 150 days), (2) Final academic session.
landmark_cases.relevance: Clarifies authorized leave requirements.

indicators: Leave from studies exceeding 150 days
Leave not authorized by DLI
Medical/personal leave without DLI documentation
Gap between semesters exceeding 150 days

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 18+ cases showing confusion about final semester exception.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Final academic session exception allows part-time status ONLY in final session. Cannot be used for multiple part-time sessions.
landmark_cases.relevance: Limits final semester exception to single final academic session only.

indicators: Part-time enrollment in multiple sessions (not just final)
Part-time enrollment in earlier semester, then full-time in final
Claimed final semester exception for non-final session

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 32+ cases showing refusal when applicant lost status and applied for PGWP before restoration granted.
indicators: Lost temporary resident status before PGWP application
Applied for restoration and PGWP simultaneously
PGWP applied while restoration pending
Restoration denied, PGWP application invalid

patterns.pattern_name: Insufficient Evidence of Employment in Foreign Entity
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 45+ cases showing this is the most common fatal refusal ground.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer reasonably refused ICT application where applicant failed to provide pay stubs, income tax returns, business ownership documents. Onus is on applicant to submit 'clear and compelling evidence'.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes evidentiary standard for proving foreign employment.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Visa officers have 'unique and localized expertise' requiring high deference. Applicant must put 'best case forward'.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms high standard of review and applicant's burden of proof.

indicators: No pay stubs from foreign employer
No income tax returns showing employment income
No business ownership documentation
No employment contract or letter of appointment
No organizational chart showing position
Discrepancies in employment dates across documents

patterns.pattern_name: Lack of Qualifying Relationship Between Entities
patterns.severity_justification: Found in 38+ cases as automatic bar to ICT eligibility.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Both entities must be 'doing business' - not mere presence of agent or office. Shell companies created solely to facilitate ICT entry do not qualify.
landmark_cases.relevance: Defines 'doing business' requirement.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Qualifying relationship requires proof of corporate structure AND both entities actively conducting business operations.
landmark_cases.relevance: Clarifies that incorporation alone insufficient.

indicators: Canadian entity incorporated shortly before application
No evidence of business operations in Canada
Company exists in name only with no employees
No physical premises secured
Unclear ownership structure between entities

patterns.pattern_name: Failure to Meet One-Year Continuous Employment Requirement
patterns.severity_justification: Mandatory requirement under FW1 Guidelines found in 32+ cases.

landmark_cases.key_holding: ICT requires continuous employment 'via payroll or by contract directly with the company' for at least one year in similar full-time position.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes strict one-year continuous employment standard.

indicators: Employment period less than 12 months
Gaps in employment history
Part-time employment without exceptional justification
Employment not in 'similar' position to Canadian role
Contract employment without direct company relationship

patterns.severity_justification: Found in 28+ cases. Start-ups face heightened scrutiny.

landmark_cases.key_holding: For start-ups, officer must assess whether Canadian entity will be 'legitimate and continuing establishment' (18-24 months minimum guideline).
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes start-up assessment framework.

landmark_cases.style_of_cause: Ghasemizadeh Bahramabadi v. Canada (Citizenship and Immigration)
landmark_cases.key_holding: Start-up must demonstrate concrete business plan, secured funding, market research, and realistic timeline.
landmark_cases.relevance: Requires substantive evidence of business viability.

indicators: No physical premises secured (for specialized knowledge roles)
Using residential address as business location
No employees hired or planned
Vague or unrealistic business plan
Insufficient capital investment

patterns.severity_justification: Found in 25+ cases. Generic industry knowledge insufficient.

landmark_cases.style_of_cause: Saghaei Moghaddam Foumani v. Canada (Citizenship and Immigration)
landmark_cases.key_holding: Specialized knowledge must be proprietary to the company - knowledge of company-specific processes not readily available externally.
landmark_cases.relevance: Distinguishes proprietary company knowledge from general industry expertise.

indicators: Knowledge described is general industry knowledge
No evidence of company-specific training
Skills readily available in Canadian labor market
Job duties do not require proprietary knowledge

patterns.severity_justification: Found in 22+ cases. First-line supervisors do not qualify.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Senior managerial position requires evidence of actual management responsibilities, not just title.
landmark_cases.relevance: Title alone insufficient - must prove actual managerial functions.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Executive/manager must primarily manage organization or major component, supervise professional staff.
landmark_cases.relevance: Defines functional test for executive/managerial capacity.

indicators: Job title claims 'manager' but duties are operational
No evidence of supervising professional employees
First-line supervisor role
No organizational chart showing reporting structure
Limited decision-making authority

patterns.severity_justification: Found in 35+ cases. Any misrepresentation can be fatal.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Applicant failed to disclose prior TRV refusal. Court held these discrepancies 'undermine overall credibility'.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes that credibility findings can be sole basis for refusal.

landmark_cases.style_of_cause: Porfirio v. Canada (Minister of Citizenship and Immigration)
landmark_cases.key_holding: Finding that applicant failed to uphold duty of candour under section 16 allows refusal under subsection 11(1) IRPA.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms s.16 violation is independent ground for refusal.

indicators: Failed to disclose prior visa refusals
Inconsistent information across forms
Discrepancies between application and supporting documents
False statements about family members
Omitted material facts

patterns.pattern_name: Lack of Temporary Intent - Dual Intent Concerns
patterns.severity_justification: Found in 30+ cases. ICT applicants must demonstrate temporary intent.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer reasonably found applicant lacked 'compelling evidence of strong ties to home country' where family already in Canada.
landmark_cases.relevance: Temporary intent required even for LMIA-exempt ICT.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Dual intent is permissible but applicant must still demonstrate will leave Canada at end of authorized period.
landmark_cases.relevance: Clarifies dual intent doctrine.

indicators: Weak ties to home country
Family members already in Canada or accompanying
Sold property or business in home country
No ongoing business or employment to return to
Previous overstays or immigration violations

patterns.severity_justification: Found in 26+ cases. Both entities must be 'doing business'.

landmark_cases.key_holding: 'Doing business' means regularly, systematically, and continuously providing goods/services. Shell companies do not qualify.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes strict 'doing business' test.

indicators: No evidence of regular business operations
No clients or customers
No revenue or financial transactions
No business license or permits
No employees other than ICT applicant

patterns.pattern_name: Position Not in Executive, Senior Managerial, or Specialized Knowledge Capacity
patterns.severity_justification: Found in 20+ cases. ICT limited to three categories under FW1 Guidelines.

landmark_cases.key_holding: ICT requires transfer to position in 'Executive, Senior Managerial, or Specialized Knowledge capacity.'
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes three-category framework.

indicators: Job duties are primarily operational/technical
Position does not require specialized knowledge
Not managing professional employees
Limited decision-making authority
First-line supervisor or team lead role

patterns.pattern_name: Timing and Sequence Raises Immigration Intent Concerns
patterns.severity_justification: Found in 24+ cases. Suspicious timing patterns suggest ICT being used as immigration pathway.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer reasonably considered timing: applicant entered Canada as tourist, wife gave birth in Canada, found residential address, registered business at that address, then filed ICT application.
landmark_cases.relevance: Timing and sequence of events can reveal true intent.

indicators: Entered Canada as visitor, then applied for work permit
Canadian entity incorporated after applicant arrived in Canada
Family members arrived in Canada before work permit application
Business registered at applicant's residential address

_search_summary.note: Limited case law available for OWP - most refusals not challenged in FC

patterns.pattern_name: Spouse OWP - Principal Applicant Status Failure
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 2024 FC 1787 - spouse OWP automatically refused when principal applicant's work permit denied.

landmark_cases.style_of_cause: Ghasemizadeh Bahramabadi v. Canada (Citizenship and Immigration)
landmark_cases.key_holding: When principal applicant's LMIA-exempt work permit was refused, spouse's open work permit under R205(c)(ii) was automatically refused.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes that spouse OWP eligibility is entirely contingent on principal applicant maintaining valid status.

indicators: Principal applicant's work permit refused
Principal applicant's status expired or invalid
Principal applicant does not meet skilled worker criteria
Business plan for principal's work deemed non-viable

patterns.pattern_name: Non-Status Open Work Permit - Renewal Refusal
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 2021 FC 326 - initial non-status OWP approval does not guarantee renewal.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Applicant received non-status open work permit in April 2018. Second OWP application refused July 2019.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes that non-status OWP is temporary relief, not a pathway to permanent status.

indicators: Currently on non-status open work permit
Applying for OWP renewal/extension
No underlying immigration application pending
Previous permit was granted as exceptional relief

patterns.pattern_name: LMIA-Exempt Work Permit - Business Viability Failure
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 2024 FC 1787 - principal's C61 ICT work permit refused due to business plan viability concerns.

landmark_cases.style_of_cause: Ghasemizadeh Bahramabadi v. Canada (Citizenship and Immigration)
landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer refused C61 ICT work permit because: (1) parent company not proven multinational, (2) business plan lacked evidence, (3) insufficient liquid assets.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes strict scrutiny for LMIA-exempt work permits supporting spouse OWPs.

indicators: Parent company not proven multinational
Business plan lacks specifics on Canadian operations
No evidence of secured premises, suppliers, or distribution channels
Insufficient liquid assets to fund startup
Minimal job creation

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 7+ cases showing 100% refusal rate when job offer found non-genuine. Results in misrepresentation finding under IRPA s.40(1)(a) with 5-year inadmissibility.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer found misrepresentation where BC PNP investigation concluded Vision Glass was not in operation at time of PR application.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes comprehensive test for genuine job offer: physical presence, business activity, communication with applicant.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Saskatchewan PNP nominee found inadmissible for misrepresentation where employer statement about work experience was fabricated.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms officers can rely on provincial and federal investigations to determine genuineness.

indicators: Employer not operating at listed address
Company website inactive or no online presence
No evidence of recent business activity
No communication between applicant and employer for extended period
Provincial investigation concludes business not legitimate

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 3+ cases showing automatic disqualification when province withdraws nomination.

landmark_cases.key_holding: BC PNP cancelled nomination after conducting own investigation. Cancellation meant applicant no longer qualified.
landmark_cases.relevance: Demonstrates province's authority to cancel nomination based on post-nomination investigation.

indicators: Province conducts post-nomination investigation
Province finds material misrepresentation in original application
Employer circumstances change significantly
Applicant fails to respond to provincial procedural fairness letter

patterns.pattern_name: Insufficient Language Proficiency for Nominated Occupation
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 5+ cases showing officer can substitute evaluation under s.87(3) IRPR when language skills insufficient.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer reasonably refused MPNP nominee with IELTS 5.0 for manufacturing manager position.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes test for s.87(3) substitution: language proficiency vs NOC occupation requirements.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Section 87(3) allows officer to substitute evaluation when nomination not sufficient indicator of economic establishment.
landmark_cases.relevance: Clarifies procedural requirement of provincial consultation before s.87(3) substitution.

indicators: IELTS/CELPIP scores below CLB 7 for management/professional positions
NOC occupation duties require communication, supervision, training
Province does not respond to officer's consultation about language adequacy

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 4+ cases showing misrepresentation finding under s.40(1)(a) when documents proven fraudulent.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Decision set aside where officer failed to consider innocent misrepresentation exception.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes narrow exception: misrepresentation made honestly by applicant who reasonably believed they were not withholding material information.

indicators: IELTS/language test results verified as non-authentic
Employment letters/references verified as false
Educational credentials found to be fraudulent
Third-party verification contradicts submitted documents

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 15+ cases showing material change in circumstances may invalidate nomination.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Change in employment circumstances after nomination can affect eligibility if material to nomination criteria.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes that post-nomination changes must be disclosed and may require provincial re-assessment.

indicators: Applicant changes employer after receiving nomination
Job duties or NOC code changes from nominated position
Employer relocates to different province
Employment relationship terminated before PR application submitted

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 10+ cases showing officer can refuse under s.87(3) when unable to demonstrate ability to become economically established.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer reasonably found applicant would not become economically established where language proficiency insufficient and no job offers.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes multi-factor test: language proficiency, job prospects, demonstrated efforts, realistic plan.

indicators: Language proficiency insufficient for nominated occupation
No job offers or employment interest in Canada
Lack of Canadian work experience or credentials
Unrealistic employment plan or expectations

patterns.pattern_name: Intent to Reside in Different Province
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 2+ cases showing violation of s.87(2)(b) IRPR requirement to intend to reside in nominating province.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Intent to reside refers to future permanent residence, not current temporary residence.
landmark_cases.relevance: Clarifies that temporary residence for studies/work does not negate intent to permanently reside in different province.

indicators: Applicant has family/ties in different province
Job search focused on provinces other than nominating province
Statements indicating preference for different province

patterns.pattern_name: Inadequate Work Experience for Nominated Occupation
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 5+ cases showing officers can assess whether work experience matches NOC requirements.
indicators: Work experience duration insufficient for NOC requirements
Job duties do not match NOC occupation description
Employment references cannot be verified
Gaps or inconsistencies in employment history

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 10+ cases across different provincial programs showing each province has specific requirements.
indicators: Failure to meet province-specific language requirements
Violation of provincial program conditions or commitments
Non-compliance with provincial settlement plan
Province-specific occupation or industry restrictions not met

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 3+ cases where decisions set aside for procedural fairness breaches.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Decision set aside where officer failed to consider innocent misrepresentation exception despite applicant's detailed response.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes duty to consider all relevant legal exceptions and applicant's evidence in reasons.

indicators: Officer fails to provide procedural fairness letter before refusal
Failure to consult province before s.87(3) substitution
Officer relies on evidence not disclosed to applicant

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 32+ cases showing 100% inadmissibility rate + 5-year ban under IRPA s.40(1)(a).

landmark_cases.key_holding: Applicant found inadmissible for misrepresentation where LMIA was obtained through fraudulent means.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms strict liability even when applicant claims to be victim of consultant fraud.

landmark_cases.key_holding: LMIA fraud discovered through ESDC investigation resulted in 5-year inadmissibility.
landmark_cases.relevance: Demonstrates ESDC-IRCC coordination in detecting LMIA fraud.

landmark_cases.style_of_cause: Chaichi Maleki v. Canada (Citizenship and Immigration)
landmark_cases.key_holding: Even when applicant is victim of consultant fraud, still responsible for application content.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms applicant responsibility principle.

indicators: LMIA obtained through unauthorized consultant
ESDC investigation reveals fraudulent recruitment
Employer has no record of LMIA application
Multiple applicants with same employer/LMIA pattern

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 25+ cases showing 75% inadmissibility rate.

landmark_cases.style_of_cause: Massamba Muaca v. Canada (Citizenship and Immigration)
landmark_cases.key_holding: Forged employment letter resulted in misrepresentation finding.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms document fraud is most serious form of misrepresentation.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Fraudulent employment documents discovered through employer verification.
landmark_cases.relevance: Demonstrates importance of employer verification process.

indicators: Employment letter format inconsistent with employer's standard
Employer denies issuing employment letter
Pay stubs do not match employer records
Tax records do not show employment income

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 15+ cases showing 100% inadmissibility rate when unauthorized consultant used.
indicators: Application prepared by unregistered consultant
Consultant not disclosed on IMM 5476
Consultant has history of fraud
Applicant cannot explain application contents

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 20+ cases showing refusal without inadmissibility ban.
indicators: Employer cannot be contacted
Job duties inconsistent with business operations
Wage significantly above or below market rate
Employer has no need for foreign worker

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 18+ cases showing refusal when employer cannot verify application details.
indicators: Employer unaware of LMIA/work permit application
Employer contact information invalid
Business not operating at listed address
Employer provides contradictory information

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 15+ cases showing 50% inadmissibility rate.
indicators: Job title differs between LMIA and work permit application
Wage differs between documents
Employment dates inconsistent
NOC code mismatch

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 12+ cases showing refusal risk when employer cannot support position.
indicators: Employer revenue insufficient to support wage
Business recently incorporated with no operations
No other employees at business
Employer has history of LMIA violations

patterns.pattern_name: Procedural Fairness Issues in Employer Verification
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 10+ cases where decisions set aside for procedural fairness breaches.
indicators: Officer did not disclose verification concerns
No opportunity to respond to adverse findings
Officer relied on undisclosed information

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 8+ cases showing this raises red flags but requires procedural fairness notice.
indicators: Job offer uses generic template language
Multiple applicants with identical job offers
Job offer lacks specific details about position

patterns.pattern_name: R200 - Not Satisfied Applicant Will Leave Canada
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 152+ cases showing this is the PRIMARY refusal ground for work permits.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer must consider dual intent when LMIA supports PR pathway.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes that dual intent is PERMISSIBLE but NOT determinative.

indicators: Weak ties to home country
Strong ties to Canada
Previous immigration violations
No compelling reason to return home

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 142+ cases showing core concern about remaining in Canada.
indicators: Family members in Canada
Previous overstay history
Sold assets in home country
No ongoing employment/business to return to

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 117+ cases showing confusion about dual intent doctrine.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer must consider dual intent when LMIA supports PR pathway, but dual intent does not eliminate R200 requirement.
landmark_cases.relevance: Clarifies that dual intent is permissible but applicant must still demonstrate will leave if required.

indicators: Concurrent PR application
LMIA supports PR pathway (e.g., Express Entry)
Applicant relies solely on dual intent without demonstrating ties

patterns.pattern_name: Weak Economic Ties to Home Country
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 98+ cases showing employment, assets, property are PRIMARY factors.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Holistic ties assessment required - economic ties are primary consideration.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes economic ties as most important factor.

indicators: No stable employment in home country
Limited property or assets
No business ownership
Low income relative to Canadian opportunity

patterns.pattern_name: Family in Canada - Strong Pull Factor
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 32+ cases showing family in Canada is significant pull factor.
indicators: Spouse in Canada
Children in Canada
Extended family in Canada
No immediate family in home country

patterns.pattern_name: Weak Family Ties to Home Country
patterns.severity_justification: Based on 24+ cases showing comparative assessment of home vs Canada ties.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Comparative ties analysis required - must assess relative strength of ties.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes comparative assessment framework.

indicators: No spouse or children in home country
Parents deceased or elderly
Siblings have emigrated
Limited social network in home country

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 27+ cases showing travel history demonstrates compliance with visa conditions.
indicators: No previous international travel
No previous visa compliance history
First-time applicant from high-refusal country

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 18+ cases showing previous refusals inform credibility assessment.
indicators: Previous work permit refusal
Previous visitor visa refusal
Previous study permit refusal
Multiple refusals from same or different countries

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 25+ cases showing 95%+ refusal rate with 5-year inadmissibility.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Any material misrepresentation triggers IRPA 40(1)(a) regardless of intent.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms strict liability for misrepresentation.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Misrepresentation includes both false statements and material omissions.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes that omissions are equally serious as false statements.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Materiality test: would the misrepresentation have affected the decision?
landmark_cases.relevance: Defines materiality standard for misrepresentation.

indicators: False information on application forms
Omission of material facts
Fraudulent documents submitted
Inconsistent information across applications

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 25+ cases showing 100% inadmissibility rate.

landmark_cases.style_of_cause: Massamba Muaca v. Canada (Citizenship and Immigration)
landmark_cases.key_holding: Forged documents are the most serious form of misrepresentation.
landmark_cases.relevance: Confirms document fraud is most serious misrepresentation.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Document verification through third parties is standard practice.
landmark_cases.relevance: Demonstrates IRCC verification capabilities.

indicators: Forged employment letters
Altered educational credentials
Fake bank statements
Fraudulent identity documents

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 15+ cases showing automatic inadmissibility for serious criminality.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Criminal inadmissibility requires criminal rehabilitation or TRP to overcome.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes pathways to overcome criminal inadmissibility.

indicators: Conviction for indictable offence
Conviction for offence punishable by 10+ years
Multiple summary convictions
Undisclosed criminal history

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 10+ cases showing permanent inadmissibility.

landmark_cases.key_holding: FINTRAC reports can be used as evidence of organized crime involvement.
landmark_cases.relevance: Demonstrates use of financial intelligence in inadmissibility determinations.

indicators: Association with criminal organization
FINTRAC suspicious transaction reports
Pattern of unexplained wealth
Links to money laundering

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 15+ cases showing 20% success rate when properly argued.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Innocent misrepresentation requires dual test: subjective honesty + objective reasonableness.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes two-part test for innocent misrepresentation.

landmark_cases.style_of_cause: Chaichi Maleki v. Canada (Citizenship and Immigration)
landmark_cases.key_holding: Must be raised in PFL response and proven with evidence.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes procedural requirements for innocent misrepresentation defense.

indicators: Applicant can demonstrate subjective honesty
Reasonable person would have made same error
Error was not due to negligence
Applicant took reasonable steps to verify information

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 10+ cases showing 30% success rate on judicial review.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Must ensure applicant actually received PFL before making inadmissibility finding.
landmark_cases.relevance: Establishes procedural fairness requirements for misrepresentation findings.

landmark_cases.key_holding: Officer must provide meaningful opportunity to respond to concerns.
landmark_cases.relevance: Defines scope of procedural fairness in inadmissibility cases.

indicators: PFL not received by applicant
Insufficient time to respond
Officer did not consider response
New concerns raised without opportunity to respond

patterns.severity_justification: Based on 8+ cases showing applicant responsible for maintaining GCKey access.
indicators: Applicant gave GCKey access to consultant
Applicant did not monitor application status
Applicant claims not to have seen PFL
Consultant made changes without applicant knowledge

HIGH.meaning: Significant refusal risk - requires strong mitigation

LOW.meaning: Minor issue - may lead to redetermination on appeal

lmia: Kataria v. Canada, 2023 FC 210 - Non-genuine job offer + s.40 misrepresentation
Liu v. Canada, 2018 FC 866 - Procedural fairness for employer finances
Jandu v. Canada, 2022 FC 1787 - Officer duty to investigate LMIA concerns
Sangha v. Canada, 2020 FC 95 - Temporary residence intent assessment
pgwp: Rehman v. Canada, 2015 FC 1021 - Full-time requirement + 8-month minimum
Kaura v. Canada, 2022 FC 51 - Strict credit requirements
Kaur v. Canada, 2024 FC 258 - Only 2 authorized exceptions
Singh v. Canada, 2020 FC 687 - Completion notification ends work authorization
ict: Chamma v. Canada, 2018 FC 29 - Comprehensive ICT requirements analysis
Arora v. Canada, 2011 FC 241 - Burden of proof and deference
Babalou v. Canada, 2024 FC 549 - Qualifying relationship requirements
Saghaei Moghaddam Foumani v. Canada, 2024 FC 574 - Specialized knowledge standard
pnp: Baniya v. Canada, 2022 FC 18 - BC PNP job offer genuineness, nomination cancellation
Ali v. Canada, 2021 FC 392 - MPNP language proficiency, s.87(3) substitution
Agapi v. Canada, 2018 FC 923 - Innocent misrepresentation exception
Haider v. Canada, 2018 FC 686 - s.87(3) framework, provincial consultation
Dhaliwal v. Canada, 2016 FC 131 - Intent to reside interpretation
Bhamra v. Canada, 2014 FC 239 - SINP fraudulent work experience
employer_fraud: Falsafi v. Canada, 2024 FC 1458 - LMIA fraud, consultant victim still liable
Mansooryan v. Canada, 2024 FC 1718 - ESDC investigation, procedural fairness
Chaichi Maleki v. Canada, 2025 FC 850 - Applicant responsibility principle
Massamba Muaca v. Canada, 2025 FC 534 - Document fraud most serious
Dini v. Canada, 2024 FC 1969 - Employer verification process
intent_ties: Singh v. Canada, 2025 FC 1210 - Dual intent when LMIA supports PR
Baring v. Canada, 2025 FC 1668 - Holistic ties assessment
Shahzad v. Canada, 2025 FC 1999 - Comparative ties analysis
admissibility: Lui v. Canada, 2025 FC 370 - Strict liability for misrepresentation
Markar v. Canada, 2022 FC 684 - Innocent misrepresentation dual test
Singh v. Canada, 2022 FC 422 - Materiality standard
Krasniqi v. Canada, 2018 FC 743 - Criminal rehabilitation pathway
Amable v. Canada, 2021 FC 702 - FINTRAC evidence in organized crime
